awd_titl_txt: Houseplants Genetically Modified for Degradation of Common Carcinogenic Indoor Air Pollutants
awd_abstract_narration:
1438266 (Strand). Home air can contain gaseous carcinogens at levels that exceed health standards for indoor environments. This project will transform a common houseplant with genes normally expressed in mammals, that are involved in the detoxification of air pollutants, including benzene, dichlorobenzene, chloroform, and acrolein, and with bacterial genes for the degradation of formaldehyde. These transgenic houseplants are expected to have the capability to help decrease the levels of carcinogens common in indoor air. The investigators will test the plants' efficacy under ambient conditions and their biosafety. This project will add to the arsenal of methods for decreasing carcinogens in the home, which make up a significant fraction of human exposures to cancer risk. This research will also clarify the widely varying rates observed by labs working on houseplant effects on air borne pollutants.

The project will introduce students and faculty to important techniques that are relatively new to the environmental engineering field. Results will be disseminated by presentations at national and international environmental engineering conferences. A web site will be prepared to showcase the results of the project.  Underrepresented groups at the K-12 and undergraduate level will be reached through the minority science and engineering program, MESP, and the mathematics, science, engineering achievement program, MESA, at the University of Washington.

por.por_cntn:
Household air is more polluted than office air and school air, and those who spend much of their time at home, such as children and home workers receive a proportionately higher dose of carcinogens than the general population. Infants are particularly susceptible to indoor air pollution due to their low body weight and continuous exposure to indoor air.  In summary, the most common and highest level cancer-causing organic indoor air pollutants are 1,4-dichlorobenzene, acrolein, formaldehyde, benzene, 1,3-butadiene, acetaldehyde, naphthalene, acrylonitrile, carbon tetrachloride, and chloroform.  In most or some homes, these pollutants occur in concentrations high enough to pose significant risk of cancer.

Several studies have suggested that common plants can remove VOCs such as formaldehyde and benzene from air, but these studies produce very variable estimates of the rate that a particular plant species removes a given pollutant from air. For example, the rates that seven plant species were found to remove benzene from the air by five different labs varied over seven orders of magnitude.  What accounts for these huge variations in plant efficacy for pollutant removal?  We think that the problem lies primarily with the inclusion of soil in the experiments combined with very high pollutant concentrations that unrealistically stimulate microbial populations to activities that are not characteristic of their activities under household air conditions. Since stimulation of pollutant degrading microbial populations with enriched pollutant levels is not possible in the home, the rates reported are not relevant to home air remediation.

However, plants do have many attractive features as a platform for metabolism of organic pollutants.  Unlike most bacteria, cultivated plants have excess energy available to support catalysis. Plants have high surface areas that facilitate mass transfer of trace gases from the air.  Plants are self-sustaining and do not require the high maintenance typical of bacterial systems. What is needed to increase the detoxification of indoor air is to add to household plants what they lack: a strong ability to metabolize VOCs.

We have shown that a common indoor houseplant, pothos ivy, can be transformed with indoor air pollutant degrading genes, i.e., the gene for cytochrome P450 2E1 and that the transformed pothos ivy can remove benzene, a CYP2E1 substrate pollutant at much higher rates than untransformed wild-type plants.

We have developed vectors with four to five stacked genes for the degradation of formaldehyde, benzene, chloroform and many other prominent indoor air pollutants. Pothos ivy has been transformed with these vectors (second generation plants) which are in successful selection culture. When the project ended about a hundred plant tissues were being cultured on regeneration media with selection pressure. 

After achieving the expression of benzene degradation in first generation pothos ivy we pursued regulatory approval to commercialize clone VD3 transformed pothos ivy. Consultation with staff of USDA Aphis in 2016 made it clear that, since pothos ivy can grow vigorously outdoors in southern Florida, it is necessary to demonstrate that our transgenic ivy is not more weedy than wild-type pothos. This process has led to definition of several biosafety experiments needed for an application for nonregulatory status in the US. Among these are to determine whether the transformed pothos ivy is more resistant to low temperatures than wild-type pothos. These experiments have been performed and found no difference in plant response to low temperature. Another test was of root growth rate from cuttings. Pothos ivy does not flower in the US, so clonal regeneration from accidental plant fragmentation (i.e., natural cuttings) is the only propagation process available to it. No difference in root growth was found between the 2e1 transgenic clone VD3 and wild-type pothos ivy.

Interestingly, we were able to obtain deregulated approval for commercialization of our transgenic pothos ivy in Canada (CFIA), since annual frost occurs all over Canada, so pothos ivy cannot survive outdoors for more than a year anywhere in Canada.

In order to reach out to the general public, Dr. Strand is posting to a Facebook page, “Superpothos” in which he showcases the results of the project by blogging about the process of genetically engineering houseplants. 

https://www.facebook.com/Superpothos-262843243841765/

After the development of clone VD3 we contacted two horticulture supplier firms and several plant biotechnology venture firms to determine their interest in commercialization of the transformed houseplant. Eventually, all parties backed out of participation.  One of their concerns was the lack of intellectual property protection under US law. To address their concerns our subsequent generations of plants have incorporated copyrighted sequences encoding an original work of art as well as increased range of pollutant degradation and improved gfp fluorescence.
